links.title: Facebook Removes Data-Security App From Apple Store
links.description: Facebook Inc. pulled its data-security app from Apple Inc.'s app store after the iPhone maker ruled that the service violated its data-collection policies, according to a person familiar with the matter.

links.title: Trump says the stock market would crash if he were impeached
links.description: President Donald Trump said the stock market would plummet if he were to be removed from office. "If I ever got impeached, I think the market would crash. I think everybody would be very poor," the president said in an interview with Fox News, which aired on Thursday.

links.title: How to Tame Android OS for Vehicles
links.description: In an earlier post, I asked engineers who develop software for connected and autonomous cars to consider the true cost of using Linux from a monetary as well as a safety-certification and security perspective. A friend emailed me after reading that post, asking why I didn't discuss the security vulnerabilities of Android and why I gave it a "hall pass".

$FB $SNAP $AAPL $MSFT $GOOGL $AMZN $IBM $ORCL $CRM $TSLA Part 2

links.title: Facebook & Snap's Attempt to Invalidate BlackBerry Lawsuit Fails - UTB Blogs
links.description: In a 28-page verdict, it was decided that most of the BlackBerry lawsuits against Facebook and Snap would remain in place. Facebook and Snap's request to invalidate the lawsuit completely was not realized. Of the seven patents being disputed, one was removed from the lawsuits.

https://9to5mac.com/2018/08/22/apple-app-store-commission-revenue/ 
https://9to5mac.com/2018/06/18/apple-antitrust-app-commissions/

links.title: Analyst says Apple's App Store could take $16B hit as commissions under fire
links.description: It was yesterday reported that Apple's App Store could lose one of its highest-grossing apps as Netflix looks to bypass iTunes billing - and one analyst thinks this may be only the beginning ... Business Insider saw a Macquarie Research note which says that both pushback from developers and regulatory intervention could force Apple to reduce its App Store commissions.

links.title: Apple asks US Supreme Court to throw out antitrust suit over app commissions
links.description: Apple has asked the US Supreme Court to dismiss an antitrust lawsuit which accuses Apple of monopolizing the app market so that it can charge excessive commissions ... The lawsuit dates back to 2011, where it was first filed in a California federal court by Robert Pepper and other iPhone buyers.
